diff.*:
Line 13: Line 13:  
[[Buddhism]] sets [[Upādāna|attachment]] and [[Taṇhā|desire]] as negative emotions that release [[anger]] and cause suffering; love and [[ego]] are incompatible. In the buddhist philosophy, true love is compassionate love.<ref name="Buddha">[http://books.google.es/books?id=VECepVHTH0QC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Guatama Buddha. ''The Dhammapada''. Translated by Irving Babbitt.]</ref> [[Jesus Christ]] also embraces interpersonal love from an [[altruism|atruistic]] and compassionate view ("love your neighbor as yourself"). [[Gottfried Leibniz]] believes that if one really understands and seeks love, he will always take pleasure in the happiness of another.<ref>[http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/journal_of_the_history_of_philosophy/summary/v015/15.3den_uyl.html The Aristocratic Principle in the Political Philosophy of Leibniz]. DJ Den Uyl - Journal of the History of Philosophy, 2008 - muse.jhu.edu.</ref>
 
[[Buddhism]] sets [[Upādāna|attachment]] and [[Taṇhā|desire]] as negative emotions that release [[anger]] and cause suffering; love and [[ego]] are incompatible. In the buddhist philosophy, true love is compassionate love.<ref name="Buddha">[http://books.google.es/books?id=VECepVHTH0QC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Guatama Buddha. ''The Dhammapada''. Translated by Irving Babbitt.]</ref> [[Jesus Christ]] also embraces interpersonal love from an [[altruism|atruistic]] and compassionate view ("love your neighbor as yourself"). [[Gottfried Leibniz]] believes that if one really understands and seeks love, he will always take pleasure in the happiness of another.<ref>[http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/journal_of_the_history_of_philosophy/summary/v015/15.3den_uyl.html The Aristocratic Principle in the Political Philosophy of Leibniz]. DJ Den Uyl - Journal of the History of Philosophy, 2008 - muse.jhu.edu.</ref>
 
 
−
On the other side, [[Sigmund Freud]] thinks that unconditional love from a mother leads to perpetual dissatisfaction: "When you were incontestably the favorite child of your mother, you keep during your lifetime this victor feeling, you keep feeling sure of success, which in reality seldom doesn’t fulfill". He describes love as a [[narcissism|narcissistic]] behavior; human beings only love what they were, what they are, what they want to be.
+
[[Gilles Deleuze]] and [[Félix Guattari]] write in ''[[Anti-Oedipus]]'', "capitalism garners and possesses the force of the aim and the interest (power), but it feels a disinterested love for the absurd and nonpossessed force of the machine. [...] to be sure, it is not for himself or his children that the capitalist works, but for the immortality of the system. A violence without purpose, [...] a pure joy in feeling oneself a wheel in the machine, traversed by flows, broken by schizzes".<ref>[http://books.google.es/books?id=4KCfPtku4qAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=anti-oedipus#v=onepage&q&f=false Anti-Oedipus]. P. 380.</ref> [[Michel Foucault]] insists in his 1977 Preface to the English edition of ''Introduction to schizoanalysis'', that he opposes to "not only fascism, but also the fascism in us all, in our heads and in our everyday behavior, the fascism that causes us to love power, to desire the very thing in our everyday behavior, the fascism that causes us to love power, to desire the very thing that dominates and exploits us".<ref>Gilles Deleuze, Eugene W. Holland. [http://books.google.es/books?id=IM_nOyU7V_UC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Deleuze and Guattari's Anti-Oedipus: introduction to schizoanalysis]. P. IX.</ref>
−
+
−
[[Humanistic psychology]] sets healthy [[self-esteem in humanistic psychology|self-esteem]] as an essential requirement for every healthy interpersonal relationship, including interpersonal love. [[Abraham Maslow]] places love at the ''love/belonging level'', between the ''safety level'' and the ''esteem level'', in his [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|hierarchy of needs]].
+
[[Humanistic psychology]] sets love as an essential requirement for a healthy [[self-esteem in humanistic psychology|self-esteem]]. [[Abraham Maslow]] places love at the ''love/belonging level'', between the ''safety level'' and the ''esteem level'', in his [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|hierarchy of needs]].
  +   +
On the other hand, [[Sigmund Freud]] thinks that unconditional love from a mother leads to perpetual dissatisfaction: "When you were incontestably the favorite child of your mother, you keep during your lifetime this victor feeling, you keep feeling sure of success, which in reality seldom doesn’t fulfill". He describes love as a [[narcissism|narcissistic]] behavior; human beings only love what they were, what they are, what they want to be.
     
[[Science]] defines what could be understood as love as an evolved state of the survival instinct, primarily used to keep human beings together against menaces and to facilitate the continuation of the species through [[reproduction]].<ref name="Fisher">Helen Fisher. ''Why we love: the nature and chemistry of romantic love''. 2004.</ref>
 
[[Science]] defines what could be understood as love as an evolved state of the survival instinct, primarily used to keep human beings together against menaces and to facilitate the continuation of the species through [[reproduction]].<ref name="Fisher">Helen Fisher. ''Why we love: the nature and chemistry of romantic love''. 2004.</ref>
